This sounds good but is not all that enlightened. Here's why:

1) It limits the benefits to someone who is employed in the city, and indirectly, to his or her spouse;

2) It is not clear if this is a temporary or permanent change of status. What if you later are not employed in Guangzhou, will the status be revoked? What if your partner is the one who applied, and now you're getting divorced? Will your children still be able to go to school for free, i.e., be treated as GZ residents? And so forth.

In summary, GZ is still seeking to limit and control who can access local low-cost or free social services such as schooling, medical treatment, etc. And you can be sure that this exception will only be extended to middle-class people; migrants -- the outsiders who clean the streets, build the buildings, do the grunt work -- will be told they aren't "eligible." Because the local government will no doubt force the employers who apply for such "hukou" for their workers to pay a higher rate of tax (in one form or another) in order to finance this new measure.

In 1806 in Virginia a court acquitted a young man who forged checks on his uncle bank account, because the bank took the hit, not the uncle. The law forbade using false writings to defraud any person. The court rule that, as the bank was not a person, it was not protected by that law. The court ruled that there was no law against defrauding a bank! The Virginia legislature passed an act declaring that a corporation was a person as least as far as such laws were concerned. I don't think this was earliest example of this sort of thing, either.

In short, the "personhood" of corporations is nothing new. And one can see why there is value in that legal fiction.

I wish you were right. You are referring to the headnote in
Santa Clara County v. Southern Pacific Railroad – 118 U.S. 394 (1886):
"The court does not wish to hear argument on the question whether the provision in the Fourteenth Amendment to the Constitution, which forbids a State to deny to any person within its jurisdiction the equal protection of the laws, applies to these corporations. We are all of the opinion that it does."

Unfortunately in Pembina Consolidated Silver Mining Co. v. Pennsylvania – 125 U.S. 181 (1888), the Court clearly affirmed the doctrine, holding, "Under the designation of 'person' there is no doubt that a private corporation is included [in the Fourteenth Amendment]. Such corporations are merely associations of individuals united for a special purpose and permitted to do business under a particular name and have a succession of members without dissolution."

Quite so.  I've often been wondering why there is no attack on the foundation of corporate "personhood".  If the politics were reversed, we can be sure there would have been a flood of position papers from the Cato Institute, the Heritage Foundation, the Manhattan Institute, and the dozens of other corporate-friendly and corporate-sponsored "think tanks".  Why are the (noncorporate) liberals lying down on the job?

What many people are unaware of is that the original decision that supposedly gave corporations "person" status was based on an error: essentially, a "margin comment" on the decision inadvertently became part of the decision itself.  And every decision since then in which "corporations as people" has been upheld has been "fruit of the poisonous tree" - error piled upon error.  Legal scholars on the left need to start "peeling back the onion" in this regard, going back to the original decision and revealing the error.  That is the only way we will ever have even a minimal chance of undoing all of the bad decisions since then - from Citizens United to Hobby Lobby and beyond.
Amen

During the 2012 presidential campaign reports revealed that Mitt Romney had an IRA with $100 million.  Contributions are limited, but growth is not.  Investment bankers can direct their IRAs into insider-type investments.  For example, when Romney was recommending the government allow GM to file bankruptcy, (reverse psychology?) his investment group bought controlling interest in a publically traded company that was one of GM's suppliers.  His group paid less than 3% of what that company had been valued at just a year earlier.  When the GM bailout was announced, the stock rebounded.  Imagine you make that kind of investment from your IRA.  You only need two deals like that to turn $50,000 into $100 million.  Most of us simply don't play in the same sandbox, do we?

While the trend of higher fraction of interest income for the rich is as expected I think the impacts on the 99% retired and near retired are much larger than indicated by the data presented for several reasons:  1)  the fraction of income from interest for those at or near retirement is much higher than the average for this group. 2)  much of the interest income for the 99% is not booked as "interest income" for tax purposes because it is within a retirement plan.  Interest income that accrues in a IRA or 401K is not booked as income at all until it is withdrawn and then it is not booked by the IRS as interest income.  The fraction of income within retirement accounts is much higher for the 99% than for the 1% because of the annual contribution limits (the rich cannot put a large percentage of their assets in these accounts).  Similarly reduced earnings of the assets of defined benefit plans increase the pressure to reduce or eliminate these plans.  3)  The returns for annuities purchased by retirees or near retirees are substantially reduced by the ZIRP.  Similar to the above these are not booked as interest income even though they are based largely on interest rates available in the market.
